turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Wilfrid Spender.
turn.2: He accepted an invitation to stand for Parliament, but withdrew when the rules were changed to place officers on half pay if they entered parliament.
turn.3: What political activities did he get involved in?
turn.4: He signed the Ulster Covenant when it was opened for signature in England.
turn.5: What were some of his other activities?
turn.6: In 1913 he was allowed to retire from his army commission, refusing to resign with the rank of Captain and £120 per year.
turn.7: Was he criticized for any of his beliefs or views?
turn.8: A confidential inspection report of 1913 commented that Captain Spender had been led away by a ‘too active conscience’ and had been very injudicious, risking his prospects in life.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: While disputing being forced to leave the army, feeling his services were required in Ulster, Spender sought legal advice from Sir Edward Carson.
turn.11: What did Sir Edward Carson advise him to do?
turn.12: He invited Spender to Belfast to help organise the Ulster Volunteer Force, a paramilitary group to resist Home Rule.
